results.title: Elizabeth Holmes caps her testimony with a round of denials.
results.abstract: The climax of the cross-examination of Ms. Holmes, founder of the blood testing start-up Theranos, sends her fraud trial to its end stage.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Holmes with her partner, Billy Evans, in September. Ms. Holmes’s testimony is expected to formally finish on Wednesday.
multimedia.copyright: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times

results.title: Instagram says parental controls will arrive in March.
results.abstract: Adam Mosseri, the head of the company, is expected to face questions from lawmakers this week about whether social media harms children.

multimedia.caption: Adam Mosseri, the head of Instagram, is scheduled to appear before a Senate committee on Wednesday.
multimedia.copyright: Ricky Rhodes for The New York Times

results.title: Inside Tesla as Elon Musk Pushed an Unflinching Vision for Self-Driving Cars
results.abstract: The automaker may have undermined safety in designing its Autopilot driver-assistance system to fit its chief executive’s vision, former employees say.
results.byline: By Cade Metz and Neal E. Boudette

multimedia.caption: A Tesla using Autopilot navigated a morning rush hour in Los Angeles.

results.title: Netflix and the Internet of Fads
results.abstract: Netflix and TikTok have supercharged fame.

results.title: Amazon’s cloud computing outage disrupts its warehouse operations.
results.abstract: Amazon Web Services began reporting increased “error rates” in its cloud operations on Tuesday morning.

multimedia.caption: Workers at an Amazon center. Company warehouses around the country stopped operating Tuesday as a result of disruptions in the company’s cloud computing system.
multimedia.copyright: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

results.title: This Robot Looks Like a Pancake and Jumps Like a Maggot
results.abstract: Researchers designed a soft, legless robot that can hop and navigate obstacle courses.

multimedia.copyright: R. Chen et al., Nature Communications 2021

results.title: Seeking Space for Solar Farms, Cities Find Room at Their Airports
results.abstract: Airports around the nation are installing solar arrays on unused land, roofs and parking garages, helping them achieve self-sufficiency while also providing power to their communities.

multimedia.caption: A grid of solar panels stretching toward the Tallahassee International Airport control tower.
multimedia.copyright: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times

results.title: On the Banks of the Furious Congo River, a 5-Star Emporium of Ambition
results.abstract: As the clean energy revolution upends the centuries-long lock of fossil fuels on the global economy, dealmakers and hustlers converge on the Fleuve Congo Hotel.
results.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Eric Lipton, Michael Forsythe and Ashley Gilbertson

multimedia.caption: The hotel rolled out the red carpet for the arrival of Mr. Tshisekedi, the president.

results.title: A New Tesla Safety Concern: Drivers Can Play Video Games in Moving Cars
results.abstract: The feature raises fresh questions about whether Tesla is compromising safety as it rushes to add new technologies.

multimedia.caption: Vince Patton demonstrated that it’s possible to play video games while driving his Tesla Model 3.
multimedia.copyright: Will Matsuda for The New York Times

results.title: Your Face Is, or Will Be, Your Boarding Pass
results.abstract: Tech-driven changes are coming fast and furiously to airports, including advancements in biometrics that verify identity and shorten security procedures for those passengers who opt into the programs.

results.title: Intel will take its Mobileye automotive unit public in 2022.
results.abstract: The chip maker’s Israeli subsidiary builds driver-assistance technology for major automakers and is now testing self-driving cars.

multimedia.caption: A Mobileye vehicle at the Nasdaq stock exchange in Manhattan. The company announced testing of its driverless cars in the city in July.

results.title: Chanel, TikTok and the Beauty Advent Calendar Controversy
results.abstract: Some social media users are not feeling the Christmas spirit — or this box of mini lipsticks and branded stickers.

multimedia.caption: The Chanel No. 5 Advent calendar from its 2021 holiday collection.

results.title: A Bitcoin Boom Fueled by Cheap Power, Empty Plants and Few Rules
results.abstract: Cryptocurrency miners are flocking to New York’s faded industrial towns, prompting concern over the environmental impact of huge computer farms.

multimedia.caption: Fans cooling a Bitcoin mining operation at the Mechanicville Hydroelectric Plant in Mechanicville, N.Y.
multimedia.copyright: Cindy Schultz for The New York Times

results.title: Is an All-Encompassing Mobility App Making a Comeback?
results.abstract: Versions of “mobility as a service,” or MaaS, apps exist, but companies and cities will need to come together for the idea to gain momentum.

results.title: When Did Spotify Wrapped Get So Chatty?
results.abstract: This year’s data dump from the streaming music service leaned heavily on contemporary buzzwords and slang — and inspired many, many memes.

multimedia.caption: For the text of this year’s Spotify Wrapped feature, the streaming music service leaned on internet slang and trending topics.

results.title: Twitter’s heads of engineering and design will leave in a company shake-up.
results.abstract: Twitter’s head of engineering, Michael Montano, and its head of design and research, Dantley Davis, will leave the company by the end of the year.

results.title: What Happened to Amazon’s Bookstore?
results.abstract: A 2011 thriller was supposed to cost $15. One merchant listed it at $987, with a 17th-century publication date. That’s what happens in a marketplace where third-party sellers run wild.

results.title: F.T.C. Sues to Stop Blockbuster Chip Deal Between Nvidia and Arm
results.abstract: The proposed deal would give Nvidia control over computing technology and designs that rival firms rely on.
results.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Don Clark

multimedia.copyright: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times

results.title: Why Didn’t the U.S. Detect Omicron Cases Sooner?
results.abstract: Genomic surveillance has improved enormously in recent months, but the system has built-in delays, and blind spots remain.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Analyzing a Covid test sample in a lab in Houston. The country is now sequencing roughly 80,000 virus samples a week and 14 percent of all positive P.C.R. tests, but the process is time-consuming.

results.title: A Journalist, a Philosophy Major and the Mad Scramble for Video Game Consoles
results.abstract: New gaming consoles remain in short supply this holiday season, spawning cottage industries of tipsters and scalpers making money off their scarcity.
results.byline: By Kellen Browning and Julie Creswell

results.title: The Year in Emojis
results.abstract: Tears of joy prevailed as the most-used emoji in 2021, despite Gen Z’s stated contempt for it.

multimedia.copyright: Jörg Carstensen/Picture alliance via Getty Images

results.title: Twitter and Facebook hit back at Chinese propaganda campaigns.
results.abstract: The social media giants removed a large number of accounts that promoted Covid-19 conspiracy theories and undermined reports of human rights abuses.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

multimedia.caption: A propaganda display in the city of Hotan, in the Chinese region of Xinjiang, earlier this year.

results.title: Square, Jack Dorsey’s payments company, changes its name to Block.
results.abstract: Mr. Dorsey has in recent years grown more fascinated by cryptocurrencies and the promise of technological decentralization that blockchain technology could allow for.

multimedia.caption: Jack Dorsey, in 2013, showing off a Square point-of-sale terminal. Mr. Dorsey has become a major booster of cryptocurrency and blockchain technology.

results.title: Those Cute Cats Online? They Help Spread Misinformation.
results.abstract: A mainstay of the internet is regularly used to build audiences for people and organizations pushing false and misleading information.

results.title: Lawmakers Target Big Tech ‘Amplification.’ What Does That Mean?
results.abstract: Some lawmakers from both parties argue that when social media sites boost the performance of hateful or violent posts, the sites become accomplices.
org_facet: House Committee on Energy and Commerce

results.title: How to Carry Your Covid Health Data on a Smartphone
results.abstract: To plan for safe travels and gatherings this holiday season, here are some simple ways to take your Covid-related health data with you.

results.title: What Will Art Look Like in the Metaverse?
results.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg wants us thinking about visual art when we contemplate his company’s new venture. Artists should take the suggestion seriously.

results.title: Prosecutors Push Elizabeth Holmes of Theranos to Take Responsibility
results.abstract: Under cross-examination, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up defended herself but admitted that she had made mistakes.

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of Theranos, leaving the courthouse last week.

results.title: Twitter will take down pictures of people posted without their permission.
results.abstract: The company said the policy was consistent with privacy laws in the European Union and elsewhere.
